newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Miffed Zurich Jews close UBS bank account.
newsitem.headline: Miffed Zurich Jews close UBS bank account.

text.p: Zurich's Jewish Community (ICZ) has closed its account at Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS) in protest at what it deemed insensitive comments from bank executives and the sacking of a night watchman who uncovered the shredding of old documents.

An ICZ spokeswoman confirmed press reports on Thursday that the city's Jewish community had withdrawn around three million Swiss francs ($2 million) from its UBS account and would now bank with rival Credit Suisse.
"We regret it on the one hand, but on the other hand we have some understanding for this," a UBS spokesman added.
He described the incident as one of the isolated cases in which UBS has lost clients because of controversy over Swiss banks' handling of dormant accounts from Holocaust victims.
ICZ closed its account at UBS at the end of June.
In press accounts, ICZ President Werner Rom cited the case of sacked watchman Christoph Meili and comments by UBS chairman Robert Studer for the move.

Studer, who once dismissed the sums in dormant accounts as "peanuts", also accused Meili on Swiss television of acting for ulterior motives when he sneaked old documents out of UBS's shredding room and handed them over to Zurich Jewish leaders. ($ = 1.461 Swiss Francs)
